![Eunhaeng Botanical Garden (ÏùÄÌñâÏãùÎ¨ºÏõê (ÏùÄÌñâÏûêÏó∞Í¥ÄÏ∞∞Ïõê))](/2022-08-23-1661247612629/1865972_image2_1.webp) ## Overview > Eunhaeng Botanical Garden is operated by Seongnam-si. The garden was originally a discarded drainage area that was transformed into an ecological park with an arboretum. The garden is rich in greenery, with a diverse range of plants, wildflowers, and insects, making it an ideal place for students to see and learn about nature. The garden is also a beautiful recreation area for local residents.

* Facility area - 34,760„é° (10,533 pyeong) / Visitor center area 202„é° (61 pyeong)
* Plants: 89 species 2,317 plants, Shrub: 78 species 13,689 shrubs, Flowering plants: 209 species 94,329 plants
* Insects - Ladybug, butterfly with four feet, Monema flavescens, Riptortus clavatus, black-tipped leafhopper, Poecilocoris lewisi, etc. ## Intro | | | | - | - | |infocenter:|‚Ä¢ 1330 Travel Hotline: +82-2-1330
(Korean, English, Japanese, Chinese)
‚Ä¢ For more info: +82-31-729-4319| |opendate:|October 30, 2002| |parking:|Available (Near the Visitor's Center or garden)| |restdate:|The day of Seollal (Lunar New Year's Day) and Chuseok (Korean Thanksgiving Day)| |usetime:|June-September 09:00-19:00
October-May 09:00-18:00| ## Detail Info | | | | - | - | |Tour Course Information:|Visitor's center - greenhouse - Miro Plaza - shrubbery garden A - azalea garden - theme circle - wild chrysanthemum garden - silver grass garden - water parsley garden - orange stonecrop garden - complex seasonal garden A - aquatic botanical garden - alpine botanical garden - lily garden - edible botanical garden - herb garden - complex seasonal garden B - shrubbery garden B - outdoor stage - eco pond| |Restrooms:|Available| |Available Facilities:|Visitor's Center, greenhouse, maze square, outdoor performance hall, ecological pond, aquatic botanical garden, herb garden, perfume garden, etc.| ## Detail Image ![/2022-08-23-1661247612629/1865975_image2_1.webp](/2022-08-23-1661247612629/1865975_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-08-23-1661247612629/1865982_image2_1.webp](/2022-08-23-1661247612629/1865982_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-08-23-1661247612629/1865983_image2_1.webp](/2022-08-23-1661247612629/1865983_image2_1.webp) ## Contact - [‚òéÔ∏è+82-31-729-4319](tel:+82317294319) - [üè†epark.seongnam.go.kr](http://epark.seongnam.go.kr/main/index.asp) ```googleMap latitude: 37.4532263470 longitude: 127.1668682019 title: 72, Eunhaeng-ro, Jungwon-gu, Seongnam-si, Gyeonggi-do ``` ## Directions [Bus]
At Namhansanseong Station (Seoul Subway Line 8), Exit 6, take Bus No. 6.
Get off at Eunhaeng-dong Community Center Bus Stop.
Walk for approx. 5 min to the garden.

data.title: Eunhaeng Botanical Garden (ÏùÄÌñâÏãùÎ¨ºÏõê (ÏùÄÌñâÏûêÏó∞Í¥ÄÏ∞∞Ïõê))
data.description:
Eunhaeng Botanical Garden is operated by Seongnam-si. The garden was originally a discarded drainage area that was transformed into an ecological park with an arboretum. The garden is rich in greenery, with a diverse range of plants, wildflowers, and insects, making it an ideal place for students to see and learn about nature. The garden is also a beautiful recreation area for local residents.

* Facility area - 34,760„é° (10,533 pyeong) / Visitor center area 202„é° (61 pyeong)
* Plants 89 species 2,317 plants, Shrub 78 species 13,689 shrubs, Flowering plants 209 species94,329 plants
* Insects - Ladybug, butterfly with four feet, Monema flavescens, Riptortus clavatus, black-tipped leafhopper, Poecilocoris lewisi, etc.
data.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Wolhwawon Garden (ÏõîÌôîÏõê)
dataList.description:
Wolhwawon Garden at the west point of Hyowon Park, located in Paldang-gu, Suwon in Gyeonggi-do, features elements that are heavily influenced by the traditional gardens of Guangdong Province in China. Wolhwawon Garden was established as a result of a special memorandom of agreement (MOU) made in 2003 between the provincial governments of Gyeonggi-do in Korea and Guangdong in China. In appreciation of each other's friendship and cultural heritages, both parties agreed to build a traditional garden that represents the other within the city. The construction of Wolhwawon began on June 15, 2005 and became open to the public on April 17, 2006.

The components and overall design of Wolhwawon Garden was inspired by traditional gardens of ancient Guangdong. The view of the garden was made to be enjoyable from inside buildings through windows. Other features include an artificial hill made of soil with a man-made waterfall and lake. The garden has a total area of 6,026 „é° and was established with the help of 80 Chinese workers who came to Korea to build this garden and financial aid of 3.4 billion won from Guangdong.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: West Five Royal Tombs [UNESCO World Heritage] (Í≥†Ïñë ÏÑúÏò§Î¶â [Ïú†ÎÑ§Ïä§ÏΩî ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ¨∏ÌôîÏú†ÏÇ∞])
dataList.description:
West Five Royal Tombs is the second largest royal burial site of the Joseon dynasty after Donggureung Royal Tombs. In Korean, the burial mounds of kings and queens are named reung or neung, while those of kings‚Äô parents, crown princes and princesses are called won, and the burial mounds of other princes and princesses are called myo.

West Five Royal Tombs consists of Gyeongneung (the tomb of posthumously designated rulers, King Deokjong and Queen Sohye), Changneung (the tomb of King Yejong, the 8th ruler, and Queen Ansun), Hongneung (the tomb of Queen Jeongseong, a consort to King Yeongjo, the 21st ruler), Ingneung (the tomb of Queen Ingyeong, a consort to King Sukjong) and Myeongneung (the tomb of King Sukjong, the 19th ruler, and his two wives, Queen Inhyeon and Queen Inwon).

In addition to the five reungs in West Five Royal Tombs, there are three wons. These include Sunchangwon (the tombs of Crown Prince Sunhoe and Crown Princess Gonghoebin), Sugyeongwon (the tomb of King Yeongjo‚Äôs concubine, Yeongbin) and Yeonghoewon (King Injo‚Äôs son, Crown Prince Sohyeon and Crown Princess Minhoebin). Also, Daebinmyo, the grave of Janghuibin who was King Sukjong‚Äôs concubine and King Gyeongjong‚Äôs mother, was recently moved to the burial site.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Wentteok Village (Ïõ¨Îñ°ÎßàÏùÑ)
dataList.description:
Wentteok Village gets its name from the word ‚ÄúWentteok‚Äù (meaning ‚Äúunexpected windfall‚Äù) and is a slow food village located in Jungneung-ri, Wonsam-myeon, Yongin-si, Gyeonggi-do. At the village, you can make traditional rice cake from fresh seasonal ingredients or make a tteok (rice cake) cake and have your own small party.

The village is a great venue to learn more about tteok (rice cakes) and to enjoy other hands-on activities such as eco-friendly farming activities and other traditional activities.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Unaksan National Recreational Forest (Íµ≠Î¶Ω Ïö¥ÏïÖÏÇ∞ÏûêÏó∞Ìú¥ÏñëÎ¶º)
dataList.description:
Unaksan Mountain rises 934.7 meters above sea level. Oddly shaped rocks and peaks make the landscape particularly beautiful. Historical relics from the Later Goguryeo period, including the site of a fortress for Gung Ye (the first king of the short-lived Later Goguryeo state) can be seen on the mountain. Majestic peaks surround Mangyeongdae, the main peak, and forests of broad-leaved trees turn striking colors in the fall.

The trails are beautiful with purple magnolias in mid-April and azaleas and mountain magnolias in May. The Unaksan Mountain Autumn Leaves Festival is held in mid-October every year as the leaves begin to turn. Together with Gwanaksan, Chiaksan, Hwaaksan, and Songaksan Mountains, Unaksan Mountain is one of the five most rugged mountains in the Central region and a popular one.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Uijeongbu Budaejjigae Street (ÏùòÏ†ïÎ∂Ä Î∂ÄÎåÄÏ∞åÍ∞úÍ±∞Î¶¨)
dataList.description: The leading Uijeongbu Budaejjigae Street is where local restaurants began to be built in 1998. Here you can taste budae jjigae (kimchi and hotdog soup), which is made by boiling Western ingredients such as ham, sausage, canned American beans, mixed with kimchi and hot pepper paste.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Typhoon Observatory (ÌÉúÌíçÏ†ÑÎßùÎåÄ)
dataList.description:
Typhoon Observatory was built on December 3, 1991 by Invincible Typhoon Korean Army. The observatory is situated on Suribong Peak, the highest point of Bikkisan Mountain. It is located 65 kilometers and 140 kilometers from Seoul and Pyeongyang respectively. It is famous in that the location is the closest to the Military Demarcation Line, being only 800 meters and 1,600 meters away from the MDL and North Korean checkpoint respectively.

The observatory houses a Christian church, Catholic church, statue of the Virgin Mary, Buddhist sanctum, belfry and other facilities where soldiers are able to participate in religious ceremonies. Also, Manghyangbi Monument for displaced person, Monument for Korean War, and Boy‚Äôs Tank Corps Memorial can be seen in the area. The Exhibition Hall presents daily necessities collected from Pilseunggyo Bridge of Imjingang in North Korea and some detection equipment that armed espionage agents used when they did infiltration after the ceasefire.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Traditional Food Town around Namhansanseong Fortress (ÎÇ®ÌïúÏÇ∞ÏÑ± Ï†ÑÌÜµÏùåÏãùÎßàÏùÑ)
dataList.description: The Traditional Food Town around Namhansanseong Fortress has many restaurants offering rice, dotorimuk (acorn jelly salad), tojongdak (whole chicken) dishes, and other traditional dishes. The area embraces almost 300 years of Korean history and the restaurants were built in traditional hanok-style buildings around Namhansanseong Fortress, a military stronghold from the Joseon dynasty.
dataList.author: korea-tour
